summary:
A native of Puerto Rico, Dr. Ramirez-Fort earned her undergraduate degree at Lehigh University and medical degree at Ponce Health Sciences University. She completed a general surgery internship at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center. After her surgical internship she completed multiple postdoctoral research fellowships in virology, dermatology, venereology, immunology, with her latest being in urological oncology and FOLH1 (aka PSMA) at Weill Cornell Medicine. Dr. Ramirez-Fort then trained in radiation oncology. 

Dr. Ramirez-Fort has authored more than 70 peer-reviewed articles, abstracts and book chapters, and has served as the lead editor for a medical textbook on human papillomavirus for Karger Publishers. She has run over 27 investigator-initiated or pharmaceutical sponsored clinical trials as sub-, co- or principal investigator.  She has gained 10 years experience in preclinical, early and late (radio)pharmaceutical and medical device development.

While early in her career, Dr. Ramirez-Fort has already been involved in a wide range of preclinical and clinical research, including studies involving the effects electromagnetic radiation (ultraviolet and ionizing radiation wavebands) on a cellular and organismal level. Her current research interest involves the development of solutions for the current COVID-19 pandemic and developing/optimizing dosimetry for antibody-based brachytherapy.

publications.description: Cutaneous injury can ignite excessive fibroproliferative growth that results in keloid formation. Keloids are associated with significant morbidity related to disfigurement and/or symptoms (e.g., pain and pruritus). First-line treatment of formed keloids involves topical or intralesional steroids. Recurrent or resistant keloids are managed by surgical excision or cryotherapy, followed by steroidal application or adjuvant irradiation. Although adjuvant irradiation appears to be most efficacious, alternative therapeutic options are needed for patients without access to radiation centers. Botulinum Toxin A (BTA) appears to have similar inhibitory effects to irradiation on the cell cycle via downregulation of pathogenic cytokines. Herein, we conducted a study to compare the efficacy of intralesional triamcinolone used alone, or in combination with BTA, in the treatment of formed keloid scars. Twenty patients with a cumulative of 40 keloids completed the study. There was no significant difference between treatment arms with respect to height vascularization, pliability, and pigmentation scores. The addition of BTA resulted in significant symptomatic improvement of pain and pruritus as compared to intralesional triamcinolone alone (p < 0.001). Irradiation is only effective when administered in the adjuvant setting where inhibitory effects on cell cycle and migration are optimized. Future studies with intralesional triamcinolone and BTA should be performed adjuvantly.
publications.name: Intralesional Triamcinolone Alone or in Combination With Botulinium Toxin A Is Ineffective for the Treatment of Formed Keloid Scar: A Double Blind Controlled Pilot Study

publications.description: Lessons learned: Hyperfractionation of lutetium-177 (177 Lu)-J591 for patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer did not appear to have any additional advantage over the single dose 177 Lu-J591 or fractionated two-dose 177 Lu-J591 therapy. Definite conclusions were challenging because of the small sample size of this study, and so further studies are needed to evaluate the viability of the hypothesis. On the basis of available data, a registration study of 177 Lu-J591 (also known as TLX591) is planned and will use the two-dose fractionation schedule (Telix Pharma Q3 2019 update https://telixpharma.com/news-media/).

ingestedContentSummary.title: Gender and disease-inclusive nomenclature consolidation of theragnostic target, prostate-specific membrane antigen (PSMA) to folate hydrolase-1 (FOLH1)

message.text: The PSMA misnomer creates a gender bias in Medicine. PSMA is expressed in the cancer-associated blood vessels of ALL non-prostatic solid tumors (and prostate cancers). This expression is meaningful enough to produce clinically actionable PET/CT images for patients with non-prostatic solid tumors, particularly those with tumors that might not be FDG PET avid in primary or metastatic states.

BioFort is pleased to announce that we have recently been granted US and UK patents on numerous methodologies related to radiopharmaceutical absorbed tumor dose optimization.

Christopher Lange, D.Phil., Christopher Poole, Ph.D., and Marigdalia Ramirez-Fort, M.D. are currently developing a proprietary platform that provides predictive target lesion dosimetry and radiopharmaceutical treatment planning for clinicians. Our platform leverages the use of Monte Carlo simulation of commercially available radiopharmaceuticals, to quantify absorbed dose deposition based on histopathological target distribution. We also optimize absorbed tumor dose by applying critical fundamental radiobiological concepts.

title.text: How to preserve male fertility before undergoing pelvic RT

message.text:
As radiation methodologies improve, so does the overall patient survival. Consequently, the concern and solutions to preserve male fertility become relevant and necessary. 

Here is a PDF of our open-access publication.

Ricardo Rossello , thank you for spearheading this effort. When we consider independence, continued colonialism or statehood as solutions to the racial segregation of Puerto Rico citizens, statehood is the ideal and obvious selection. Tony Melé, my concern with independence is that any number of power (and money) hungry individuals or groups would establish an independent government form that would drive a greater socioeconomic divide between the people and further deprive Puerto Ricans of Self-Determination and of their “Nationality”. When Quebec wanted to leave Canada, the International Court of Justice determined that because the people had adequate representation, they couldn’t. On the other hand, when the English colonists were denied adequate representation with the English Crown, they left. The root of our problem is our persistent state of racial segregation (because we are not English) and denial of our fundamental rights as American Citizens (because we are not English). Let us obtain our equal protections under the law and see how our quality of life changes, before proposing an understandable solution (i.e., independence) that could make us susceptible to relive the horrid fate of Cubans under Fidel’s regime. 

#VotoPresidencial

Filled with gratitude about this last week’s efforts to rally around statehood. 125 delegates visited virtually all 100 Senate offices. Governor Pedro R. Pierluisi was able to get support for his bill from Leader Schumer that lays out a process for the people of Puerto Rico to determine the future of the island’s political status. We now have 26 co-sponsors in the senate.   

Thanks to this effort, Senator Manchin will be calling a hearing soon. It was a great week and I’m excited to be part of this beautiful future being built!  

#ExtendedDelegates #rally #puertorico #statehood #nuestracausaespoderosa

ingestedContentSummary.title: Obteniendo el Voto Presidencial, Obtenemos Nuestra IGUALDAD! (@Marigdalia)

message.text:
Yesterday, my campaign Director, posted my latest video explaining that equal treatment of Puerto Ricans is giving Puerto Ricans in Puerto Rico their fundamental and constitutional right to vote. Extrapolating from the Downes v Bidwell 1901 decision, the Supreme Court ruling explains that the reason Puerto Ricans cannot vote for the president from Puerto Rico is specifically because the majority of the inhabitants of Puerto Rico are of an alien race to the Anglo-Saxons. This is what racial segregation looks like! This is what racial discrimination looks like!

Yesterday afternoon, the video had nearly 100 views. This morning, the video only has 6 views. What happened YouTube? Did I hit the nail on the head?

https://lnkd.in/eBZpdpWx

Please watch and share!

message.text:
BioFort collaborators have just published an open-access (free) article in the Frontiers in Medicine Research Topic, "Women in Science -- Nuclear Medicine 2024".

Marigdalia Ramirez-Fort, M.D.
Barbara Meier-Schiesser
Christopher Lange
Migdalia Fort, M.D.

Please read our opinion article, towards reducing the PSMA gender and disease bias, by consolidating PSMA nomenclature to the the name of the gene that encodes the enzyme target, namely, FOLH1. 

https://lnkd.in/ef_SaBGe

commentary.text: Jose Torres I completely agree with you and with Jorge. For the sake of all of these arguments and exposés, it becomes easier to understand and predict the behavioral patterns of Puerto Rico’s governance when we understand that Puerto Rico is a Plutocracy. The data fits the model.

Jose Torres, Puerto Rico is currently run as a plutocratic state in which members of both main political parties enrich themselves through monopolizing political power, state/federal contracts, educational opportunities, employment opportunities and the excessive taxation of the people. Look at how it has been essentially impossible for new and upcoming political parties to have their candidates on the ballot for the 2024 elections. It is every citizen’s right to run for public office. The individuals that run this plutocracy attempt to claudicate or to destroy any threat to their monopolies. These people do not want our status to change no matter how much they pretend that they do, or it would have changed already. This is why I am staying in race until the very end—I am able to advocate based on my personal experience. Things have to change. And I believe it is absolutely achievable to obtain our right to the presidential vote. We don’t have to invent the wheel, because the path to our freedom has been already paved for us by the American civil rights movement.

Javier Ortiz yes, I have seen and commented on JLR’s posts. Most recently re: P. del S. 1143. I wrote: “I see a conflict of interest. As things are now, the state government excessively taxes the working class in the private sector. This excessive taxation drives the (private) working class into the forced choice between falling into poverty, joining the public sector or leaving the island. This tax money that is taken from the working class then foots the bill for the excessive redundancies and unproductivity of the public sector— also, the money flows into the excessive local expenditures for “public projects“. Now, it appears that the local Senate wants more taxpayer money to pay for several more days of paid-time-off for public workers. Puerto Rico has one of the largest and most expensive local governments in the United States that is not justified by its size nor its population. The local government provides public workers with job security, the means to pay for basic needs and to support their families. During election year, the public workers then seem to be the only ones with the paid-time-off to afford to “volunteer” on political campaigns. I see a conflict of interest here that is too big to ignore.”

Jose Torres, you are spot on. Each time a stone is turned in Puerto Rico, more corruption is uncovered. First, I still have the 2021 letter I wrote to the department of economic development for assistance in developing my patented methodologies and technologies related to Radiopharmaceuticals and Global BioDefense. I aimed to pioneer this industry in Puerto Rico and to generate numerous jobs for our local STEM and healthcare talent. To this day, I have yet to receive a response letter. Second, it has now been almost 2 years that I am waiting for permits to open my Guaynabo medical consultancy to the public. Why does it take so long for a medical clinic to receive permits? Lastly, since 2018 I have been appling to the university of Puerto Rico nuclear medicine residency training program. The university of Puerto Rico rejected me, just recently, from a position that I am clearly overqualified for. Why? I agree that arguing our status is not as important as fighting the corruption and restructuring the local taxation to allow the people to have the opportunity for economic development. I believe that with our right to the presidential vote, we citizens will gain the power to secure our own economic future!!

Tony Melé, is not OK for you to imply that the political situation of Puerto Rico, is a woman’s fault. When a person in your elevated faculty makes a sexist statement, you cause the masses to subconsciously redirect their generalized anger and frustration towards the women in their lives. We already have a problem with domestic violence in Puerto Rico. Please don’t make it worse. Can we agree for you to remove the sexist remarks?

To akin, Puerto Rican politics to the fickleness of a “woman“ is sexist. Sexist comments are no better than the racist resolves in the US Supreme Court insular cases. Yes, I agree that there are severe and deep, rooted problems within the local rulings of Puerto Rico. But, if the people were permitted to self determinate, and there were greater involvement of the US federal government in Puerto Rico (via statehood), many of these issues would improve or resolve.

Tony Melé, thank you for your nomination of my candidacy for President of Puerto Rico. Should Puerto Rico become an independent nation, and a democracy were to be established, I would certainly run for President. For a democratic government to be successfully installed in Puerto Rico, we would require the full support of the United States Federal Government in a manner that would parallel the Reconstruction Era of the South, post-American Civil War. ONLY the United States could provide the protections needed and could enforce the Democratic government desired, so that we, Puerto Ricans, do not succumb to fascist rule. However, in this current political era, I believe that statehood is our optimal choice and solution to the current inequalities and poor quality of life; the choice of statehood is in the best interest of our people. Therefore, I kindly request that during these elections we focus on my candidacy for Resident Commissioner 2024, knowing that my political views are a matter of public record (e.g., Court dockets, social media posts) and believing that in Congress, I aim to argue for our equality and to strive for our statehood!
Interestingly, yesterday this video had over 80 views, today it seems that YouTube decided to lower the view counts to 6 views. Tisk tisk YouTube!!

I see a conflict of interest. As things are now, the state government excessively taxes the working class in the private sector. This excessive taxation drives the (private) working class into the forced choice between falling into poverty, joining the public sector or leaving the island. This tax money that is taken from the working class then foots the bill for the excessive redundancies and unproductivity of the public sector— also, the money flows into the excessive local expenditures for “public projects“. Now, it appears that the local Senate wants more taxpayer money to pay for several more days of paid-time-off for public workers. Puerto Rico has one of the largest and most expensive local governments in the United States that is not justified by its size nor its population. The local government provides public workers with job security, the means to pay for basic needs and to support their families. During election year, the public workers seem to be the only ones with the paid-time-off to afford to “volunteer” as: “endorsement collectors”, “vote counters”, “fillers” at campaign events, etc. I see a conflict of interest here that is too big to ignore. #quidproquo

Dear Attorney Rodriguez-Alonso, I am moved to comment on your post, even though I do not know you personally. I am moved, because your words struck a cord that I would like to share with you and all Puerto Rican professional women. We’ve all experienced how difficult it is to succeed professionally, in a culture like ours, simply because we don’t have a Y chromosome. I was recently engaged to a Puerto Rican-Cuban attorney who became my fiancé and campaign director. He betrayed me in both realms. Your post mentions that your husband believes in you and encourages you to grow. My ex-fiancé never believed in me as a physician, a scientist or that I could become the next Resident Commissioner of Puerto Rico. I’ve had suitors since him and recently had to defend my unmarried status with the following statement: “I am looking for a husband. He needs to be XY genotype, and masculine phenotype, heterosexual and monogamous. He needs to be fertile, able to have children, be willing to stay and rear them with me as a team. Most importantly, he needs to respect me, be honest, and treat me well.” From now on, I will include that he must demonstrate that he believes in me too.

This publication came in time for International Women’s Day! But, our work is not done. We as the medical and scientific communities need to strive for gender equity in medical/scientific terminology and nomenclature, so that women do not continue to be excluded from diagnostic and therapeutic opportunities.
